title: 111_hr4567
content:
The Act titled "Civilian Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act (CEJA) of 2010" addresses accountability for criminal acts of federal contractors and employees outside the United States. The Civilian Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2010 amends Chapter 212A of title 18, United States Code, to extend jurisdiction over federal contractors and employees committing offenses outside the United States. The Civilian Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2010 expands jurisdiction over federal contractors and employees committing offenses outside the United States. Prosecution for such offenses can only occur if a foreign government has not already prosecuted the individual, with approval required from the Attorney General or Deputy Attorney General. Offenses covered include arson and assaulting or resisting. The Civilian Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2010 expands jurisdiction over federal contractors and employees committing offenses outside the United States. Offenses covered include assault, bribery, military passes, official badges, extortion, and threats. The Civilian Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2010 extends jurisdiction to federal contractors and employees for various offenses committed outside the US, including extortion, threats, and the use of firearms in violent crimes. The Civilian Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2010 expands jurisdiction to federal contractors and employees for offenses committed outside the US, including kidnapping, obstruction of justice, tampering with witnesses, and money laundering. The Civilian Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2010 broadens federal jurisdiction to include offenses committed outside the US, such as robbery, sexual abuse, terrorism, torture, treason, war crimes, and manufacturing. The Civilian Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2010 expands federal jurisdiction to cover offenses committed abroad, including drug-related crimes subject to a minimum 20-year imprisonment. The Civilian Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2010 extends federal jurisdiction to cover individuals working for US government departments or agencies outside the country, as long as their employment supports a program for the government. The Civilian Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act of 2010 extends federal jurisdiction to cover individuals working for US government departments or agencies outside the country, as long as their employment supports a program for the government. The term 'accompanying any department or agency of the United States other than the Armed Forces' refers to dependents of civilian employees, contractors, subcontractors, grantees, and their employees. The term 'grant agreement' refers to a legal instrument described in specific sections of title 31, excluding an agreement with the Armed Forces. It applies to individuals working for US government departments or agencies outside the country, provided their work supports a government program, and they are not nationals or residents of the host nation. Sec. 3273. Regulations: The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of State, and the Director of National Intelligence, will establish rules for handling individuals mentioned in sections 3271 and 3272 of this title. Chapter 212A of title 18, United States Code, deals with extraterritorial jurisdiction over offenses committed by Federal contractors and employees outside the United States. The table of sections and chapters have been amended to reflect these changes. Regulations will be established by the Attorney General in consultation with other government officials. SEC. 3. INVESTIGATIVE UNITS FOR CONTRACTOR AND EMPLOYEE OVERSIGHT. The Attorney General, in consultation with relevant government departments, shall establish Investigative Units for Contractor and Employee Oversight to investigate criminal offenses under chapter 212A of title 18, United States Code. The Attorney General, in consultation with relevant government departments, shall establish Investigative Units for Contractor and Employee Oversight to investigate criminal offenses under chapter 212A of title 18, United States Code. These regulations shall also outline responsibility for investigating incidents involving unlawful weapon discharge or serious harm caused by government personnel not in the Armed Forces. The Attorney General has the authority to investigate and enforce chapter 212A of title 18, United States Code. They can initiate, conduct, and supervise investigations of alleged offenses under this chapter. The Attorney General may also designate and authorize law enforcement personnel for arrest. The Attorney General can authorize law enforcement personnel from various federal departments to arrest individuals outside the United States if there is probable cause to believe they committed offenses under specific sections of the United States Code. The Attorney General may establish procedures to ensure that federal law enforcement agencies refer these offenses for prosecution. The Attorney General can request assistance from other Executive agencies to enforce specific sections of the United States Code, including assigning additional personnel and resources to an Investigative Unit for Contractor and Employee Oversight. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of State, must submit an annual report to Congress on the number of offenses under chapter 212A of title 18, United States Code, investigated and referred for prosecution by Federal law enforcement authorities. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of State, must submit an annual report to Congress on the number of prosecutions and investigations under chapter 212A of title 18, United States Code, including recommendations for legislative or administrative action. The term "Executive agency" is defined in section 105 of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE.

This Act and its amendments will take effect immediately upon enactment. The Attorney General and relevant Federal agencies have 90 days to ensure compliance.

SEC. 5. RULE OF CONSTRUCTION.

No provision in this Act shall limit extraterritorial jurisdiction under other Federal laws.

SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2010 through 2015 to enable the Attorney General to implement this Act.
